newsitem.title: USA: Microsoft repeats sees slower FY98 growth.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft repeats sees slower FY98 growth.

text.p: Microsoft Corp. Chief Financial Officer Michael Brown repeated that the company expects slower growth in its next fiscal year as it cranks up R&D and sales and marketing investments without a major product upgrade.

Brown said in an interview before addressing a conference on intellectual capital at Stanford University's Hoover Institution that Microsoft will continue to grow R&D levels while also investing more in sales and marketing than it has this year.
"There will be continued margin pressure from R&D. We'll invest in the sales and marketing group a little more next year than last year, probably," Brown said.
Microsoft has said it is spending more than $2 billion on research and development (R&D) in the current fiscal year.
Brown also reiterated the company's expectations of lower growth for fiscal 1998. "The growth rate will be way down," Brown said.

"It doesn't mean we won't have great products. It's a relatively flat spot in the product cycle, and then things will go back up again," he said, referring to the company's 1998 fiscal year, which begins July 1, 1997.
Brown declined to discuss business in the company's current quarter to the end of June, noting it has already entered the mandated "quiet period" ahead of reporting results.
Microsoft earned $0.79 a share in its March quarter and analysts estimate it will produce the same figure in its fourth quarter, according to First Call consensus estimates.
